raw_text:
Radcliffe will compete in London
 
 Paula Radcliffe will compete in the Flora London Marathon this year after deciding her schedule for 2005.
 
 The 31-year-old won the race in 2002 on her marathon debut, defended her title 12 months later and will now seek a third title in the 17 April race. "It doesn't get any better than this for the 25th anniversary," said race director David Bedford. "After announcing the greatest men's field ever we now have the greatest women's distance runner ever." Three years ago Radcliffe smashed the women's world record in two hours 18 minutes 15 seconds.
 
 The Bedford star returned to London 12 months later, lowering her mixed-race world record of 2:17:18, which she set in Chicago in October 2003, by one minute 53 secs. Radcliffe's career took a setback when she failed to complete the Olympic marathon and later dropped out of the Athens 10,000m last August. But the 31-year-old bounced back to win the New York Marathon in November. Radcliffe, however, passed up the chance to go for the "Big City" marathon grand slam. With wins in Chicago, London and New York, only the Boston Marathon remains to be conquered but that takes place a day after London. "Boston is definitely a race I want to do at some point, but London is very special to me," said Radcliffe. "I don't pick races thinking about things like pressure. I pick the ones in my heart I really want to do. "I love the atmosphere, crowds and course and know it will always be a great quality race. "It is also the 25th anniversary this year which adds to the occasion."
llama3.2:1b: Paula Radcliffe will compete in London's Flora London Marathon in April, seeking her third title after winning in 2002 and defending in 2003. She will attempt to break the women's world record and return the greatest men's field ever, following a career that includes smashing the two-hour 18-minute 15-second women's marathon world record three years ago.
llama3.2:3b: Paula Radcliffe will compete in the Flora London Marathon on April 17, seeking her third title in the event. She won the marathon twice previously in 2002 and 2003, setting world records each time. Despite a setback when she failed to complete the Olympic marathon and dropped out of the Athens 10,000m, Radcliffe has bounced back with wins in Chicago and New York Marathons.

Her comeback from a setback including missing the Olympics and withdrawing from an Athens race is highlighted by her victory at New York's marathon last year. Radcliffe will be competing in the 25th anniversary of the Flora London Marathon, with hopes to achieve another historical victory.

The event marks Radcliffe's return to London following a setback during the Olympics and she looks forward to racing alongside legendary male athletes.

She chose to skip Boston marathon due to pressure concerns and picked London for personal reasons including special atmosphere and anniversary significance.
opencoder:1.5b: "Radcliffe will compete in London after deciding her schedule for 2005. He won the race in 2002 on her marathon debut and dropped out of the 17 April race, which was a remarkable achievement. After defending her title, Radcliffe sought another title but struggled to keep momentum. He passed up the challenge and decided to focus more on the Big City Marathon for one last day before heading straight to London."
smollm:1.7b:
Radcliffe will compete in London for the first time since her debut in 2002. She won the race on her marathon debut, defending her title in 2002 and will now seek a third title in the 17 April race. The 31-year-old has been preparing for this event for three years, having set a new world record in 2005 after deciding her schedule for 2005.

Radcliffe's best time in London was achieved on 2002 when she won the race by one minute 18 seconds. This achievement will be remembered as one of the greatest performances by any woman in the history of the marathon. The 31-year-old returned to London two years later, lowering her mixed-race world record of 2:17:18, which she set in Chicago in October 2003, by one minute 53 seconds. Radcliffe's career took a setback when she failed to complete the Olympic marathon and later dropped out of the Athens 10,000m last August. But the 31-year-old bounced back to win the New York Marathon in November.

Radcliffe, however, passed up the chance to go for the "Big City" marathon grand slam. With wins in Chicago, London and New York, only the Boston Marathon remains to be conquered but that takes place a day after London. "Boston is definitely a race I want to do at some point," said Radcliffe. "I don't pick races thinking about things like pressure. I pick the ones in my heart I really want to do. "I love the atmosphere, crowds and course and know it will always be a great quality race. "It is also the 25th anniversary this year which adds to the occasion."

Paula Radcliffe will compete at the Flora London Marathon this year, following her 2005 decision and having previously won the race in 2002 on her marathon debut, defending it in 2004 after a long illness. She improved her women's world record from 2:17:18 to 2:18:13 in 2003 but faced setbacks including failing the Olympic marathon and dropping out of the Athens marathon last August. Despite these, she has wins in Chicago and New York and aims to do the Boston Marathon next. She expresses special sentiment about London's atmosphere and significance.
tinyllama:1.1b: Radcliffe, the legendary Flora London Marathon winner, has announced her intention to compete in the race for the third consecutive year after winning it in her marathon debut in 2002. The 31-year-old will seek to defend her title on April 17, with the greatest women's field ever set for this year's event. Three years ago, Radcliffe smashed the women's world record in a race that set a new benchmark for marathons. Two years later, she reduced her own world record even more, improving her time by 1 minute and 53 seconds to win the race against mixed-race athletes from around the globe. Despite missing out on the Athens Olympic marathon due to injury, Radcliffe rebounded with a dominant performance in New York, winning the women's New York Marathon for the second year running in November. She then passed up the chance to take part in the Boston Marathon, which takes place the day after London. However, the Flora London Marathon remains one of her top goals and Radcliffe is expected to do well at this year's race, which is marked by special significance given its 25th anniversary year.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Radcliffe (formerly Paula) will compete in London in the Flora London Marathon this year after winning the 2002 race and defending her title for the third time in 2005. David Bedford, race director, called the field "the greatest men's ever" and added that Radcliffe now holds the biggest women's marathon record of all-time. The legendary runner returns to London in 2007 to defend her title once again.
phi:2.7b: Paula Radcliffe has been confirmed as competing in the Flora London Marathon next year after winning three consecutive titles in Chicago, London and New York. She set world records in both the women's marathon and the mixed-race marathon before narrowly missing out on the 2004 Olympic marathon. However, she bounced back by winning the New York Marathon. Despite having won four races already this season, Radcliffe has decided to focus on her fifth title at the 17 April race in London, which is particularly special for her as it marks the 25th anniversary of the event.

Radcliffe loves London and is looking forward to returning to the race. It is also the 25th anniversary of the event this year.

Her career faced a setback after she withdrew from the Athens Olympic marathon and failed to complete her 10,000m race in August 2004. However, Radcliffe bounced back by winning the New York Marathon in November. Although she has won major marathons globally, including Chicago, New York, and the upcoming Boston Marathon, London holds a special place for her due to its 25th anniversary this year. Radcliffe prioritizes races that resonate with her heart over external pressures, cherishing the atmosphere, crowds, and course in London.
